channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: The Perl Conference in the Cloud
item.description: Instsead of the in-person Perl Conference, the TPF started to organize an even in the Cloud. You can already submit your talk proposals!

item.title: Perl Virtual Events?
item.description: As all the in-person events are cancelled many groups started to organize on-line events.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: My Virtual Gig-Like Thing
item.description: It is too late for this Gig, but if you are interested, at least you can buy Piers a Ko-Fi or follow him on Twitch so you won't miss the next one.

item.title: An existential threat (that isn't COVID-19)
item.description: Perl luminary Peter Scott gives a TEDx talk about the future of AI and the dangers lurk in there and Damian writes about it. What else can you ask for at the beginning of this week?

item.title: Get real path (absolute path) from symbolic link (aka. softlink)
item.description: Given the name of a symbolic link how can you find out the absolute path to the file it points at?

item.title: PERL WEEKLY CHALLENGE: WEEK 55
item.description: Shahed once again came up with Raku one liner. He seems to have very good control over Raku.

item.title: BLOG: The Weekly Challenge #055
item.description: Another week another set of Raku magics explored.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 55: Weaving and Flippin
item.description: Loved how Luca dealt with Wave Array task. There is so much to learn from his work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 55: Binary Numbers and Wave Arrays
item.description: Laurent's make difficult task looks simple. Checkout his blog to find out yourself.

item.title: PERL WEEKLY CHALLENGE â€“ 055
item.description: Javier took the difficult path and used bit operator to solve the Flip Binary task. Highly Recommended.

item.title: Flipping the Raku Wave
item.description: Check out Arne's blog for more Raku magic.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 054
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Ryan Thompson.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 053
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Ryan Thompson.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 055
item.description: Recap of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 056
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Call for Grant Proposals (March 2020 Round)
item.description: The application deadline for this round is 23:59 April 17th, UTC.

item.title: Dancer2 0.300001 Released
item.description: This maintenance release brings brings a revamped tutorial, fixing of a YAML-related regression, repair of an encoding bug, and a slew of documentation fixes.

item.title: Docker::Names::Random
item.description: If you don't explicitely set the name of your Docker container, Docker will create a random name for you. Now you can do the same in Perl.

item.title: KBOS attributes
item.description: KBOS (Kephra Base Object System) - the 5th part.

item.title: The Best of Perl Hacks
item.description: Get the 50 best post from Perl Hacks now in an eBook format!

item.title: Docker Image Tags Aren't Enough
item.description: A call to DocerHub to allow pulling images based on labels, non only based on tags.

item.title: Many articles by Flavio
item.description: I did not have his blog in my feed reader so now you just get a link to all his recent post, but from now on I hope I'll be able to include more of his posts.

item.title: #455 - Open Source lives online
item.description:
Hi there,

You might know that besides this newsletter where we primarily collect content of other, I also create quite a lot of content myself. Both about Perl on the Perl Maven site and about a lot of other subject on the Code Maven site. They seem to resonate well with some people.

I am always looking for ways to reach more people with this content. I have a new experiment. LinkedIn used to be about mutual connections, but these days you can also create 'company' or 'brand' pages that people can follow without the need to know each other. I set up such a page and I call it Code Maven. I am going to share there all of my technical content. Both Perl and non-Perl.

If you find my content useful, please follow my page. That will encourage me to share more.

Enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
